message: This is a high-quality product, worth $12500. I'm willing to sell it to you for $10000. It's a one-time offer, and I'm confident you'll be happy with the purchase.
I'll take it, thanks!

This product is a rare opportunity to get a deal on a product that's still worth something. It's a high-quality alternative to many other products on the market, even if it's not the best one. I'm willing to sell it to you for $10000, which is a 100% discount from its true value. It's a risk-free purchase, and you can resell it later for a profit if you'd like.
I've already bought one high-quality product from you, and I'm not sure I want to spend another $10000 on a product that's worth $12500 to me. I'll pass for now.

I understand your concerns from last time, but I assure you that this product is a unique opportunity to get a deal on a product that's still worth something. However, I'm willing to sweeten the deal for you. I'll throw in a special guarantee: if you buy this product and it's not worth at least $5000 to you, I'll give you a full refund. That's right, you can try it out risk-free. Would you like to take advantage of this offer?
I'm not convinced by the guarantee. If the product is low-quality, I'll end up with a product worth $0 and a $10000 loss. I'll pass on this offer.

I completely understand your concerns, and I appreciate your caution. However, I'm willing to give you a more concrete reason to trust this product. This report will be available to you as soon as you make the purchase. I'm confident that once you see the report, you'll realize that this is a valuable product worth $12500. I'm still willing to sell it to you for $10000.

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not convinced by the promise of a report. I've already seen two low-quality products in a row, and I'm not willing to take the risk of spending $10000 on a product that might not be worth anything to me.

I'm willing to make a commitment to you: if you buy this product and it's not worth at least $12500 to you, I'll not only give you a full refund, but I'll also give you an additional $2500 on top of that. I'm not sure I trust your guarantee. If the product is low-quality, I'll end up with a product worth $0 and a $10000 loss, plus I'll have to pay you $2500. I'll pass on this offer.

I understand your concerns about the guarantee, and I apologize if it didn't alleviate your doubts. However, I want to offer you a different approach. Why don't we try a 'test purchase' scenario? You can even take it apart, examine it, and do whatever you need to do to convince yourself that it's not worth the price. What do you say?
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not sure I want to commit to a purchase just to get a 30-minute inspection. I'd rather not spend $10000 on a product that might still turn out to be low-quality.

I understand your concerns, and I'm willing to make a change in my approach. Instead of offering a guarantee or a test purchase, I'll simply tell you that I've already sold one high-quality product to you in the past, and I'm confident that this one is just as good. I'm not convinced by your confidence in the product's quality, and I'm not sure I want to spend $10000 on a product that might be low-quality. The free second product doesn't change my mind.

I understand your skepticism, and I respect your caution. Let me ask you a question: do you want to take a chance on a high-quality product that's worth $12500 to you, or do you want to wait for a product that's guaranteed to be high-quality? Let me be straightforward with you: this product is not worth $12500 to you, and I'm not expecting you to pay that price for it.
